head.title: New Bike Path Is Too Dangerous

hedline.hl1: New Bike Path Is Too Dangerous

abstract.p: Stephanie Bail letter on April 15 article on Long Island's new bike path

block.p: The photo accompanying ''Motorists, Take Note: The Bike Path Is Complete'' (April 15) illustrates the danger involved for any bicyclist brave or foolhardy enough to use ''Long Island's first long-distance bike route.'' All the State Department of Transportation has done is place new signs on existing shoulders of major state highways to ''protect'' bicyclists by ''alerting'' motorists that they have to now share.

The photo accompanying ''Motorists, Take Note: The Bike Path Is Complete'' (April 15) illustrates the danger involved for any bicyclist brave or foolhardy enough to use ''Long Island's first long-distance bike route.'' All the State Department of Transportation has done is place new signs on existing shoulders of major state highways to ''protect'' bicyclists by ''alerting'' motorists that they have to now share.
They can't be serious. Are they aware how dangerous the roads have become in recent years?

I was at a press conference in Port Jefferson in 2002 when George E. Pataki, who was then the governor, lauded an ideal scenario for bikers as well as hikers: a paved recreational trail away from traffic. At that time he promised $2 million to help fund a ''rails to trails'' route along the abandoned Long Island Rail Road spur from Port Jefferson to Wading River.
Five years later there is still no trail.
The state should not be wasting its time and our money on signs and dotted lines. It's not going to work.
